title: 113_s2786
content: The Corporate Inverters Earnings Stripping Reform Act of 2014 may be cited as the "Corporate Inverters Earnings Stripping Reform Act of 2014". Additional rules related to inverted corporations are included in the Act. The Corporate Inverters Earnings Stripping Reform Act of 2014, also known as the "Corporate Inverters Earnings Stripping Reform Act of 2014," includes special rules for earnings stripping and related party transactions under Section 7874 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. These rules modify the limitation on interest deduction for applicable entities in additional limitation years. Carryover to other taxable years is not allowed. The Corporate Inverters Earnings Stripping Reform Act of 2014 includes rules for interest deduction limitations in additional limitation years under section 163(j). Subparagraphs are disregarded and substituted to determine if the interest limitation rules apply. The Corporate Inverters Earnings Stripping Reform Act of 2014 sets rules for interest deduction limitations in additional limitation years under section 163(j), where adjustments are made to determine the corporation's excess interest expense. The Corporate Inverters Earnings Stripping Reform Act of 2014 establishes rules for interest deduction limitations in additional limitation years under section 163(j) for applicable entities. Each entity must file an annual application for approval agreements with the Secretary. If an entity fails to file an application or the approval agreement lacks necessary provisions, deductions for transactions with foreign related persons are disallowed, intangible property transfers are disregarded, and cost-sharing arrangements are affected. The approval agreement specifies provisions to ensure compliance with tax regulations for transactions between related entities, disregarding cost-sharing arrangements with foreign related persons. The term `approval year' refers to any taxable year after the enactment date within a 10-taxable-year period for applicable entities, defined as corporations in an expanded affiliated group with a surrogate foreign corporation. The text chunk discusses amendments to the tax code regarding the treatment of noncorporate entities as members of an expanded affiliated group. It includes changes such as substituting certain terms and disregarding specific clauses. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act.
